docs.snippet: The only American skipper left in an round-the-world sailing race snapped his mast in choppy South American seas and limped back toward port yesterday.     Brad Van Liew, 31, of Santa Monica, Calif., had been in a tight race for second place in Class...
docs.lead_paragraph: The only American skipper left in an round-the-world sailing race snapped his mast in choppy South American seas and limped back toward port yesterday. Brad Van Liew, 31, of Santa Monica, Calif., had been in a tight race for second place in Class II of the Around Alone regatta when his mast broke Sunday afternoon.
docs.abstract: Brad Van Liew, only American skipper left in Around Alone sailing race, snaps his mast in choppy South American seas and limps back toward port (S)

docs.snippet: James D. McCawley, an internationally renowned linguist who sought wherever possible to combine in his work his three consuming passions -- language, music and ethnic food -- died on Saturday after collapsing on the campus of the University of...
docs.lead_paragraph: James D. McCawley, an internationally renowned linguist who sought wherever possible to combine in his work his three consuming passions -- language, music and ethnic food -- died on Saturday after collapsing on the campus of the University of Chicago, where he had taught for more than three decades. He was 61 and lived in Chicago. The apparent cause was a heart attack, university officials said.
docs.abstract: James D McCawley, internationally renowned linguist who sought wherever possible to combine in his work three consuming passions--language, music and ethnic food--dies at age 61; photo (M)

headline.main: James D. McCawley, Linguist Who Stirred a Rift, Dies at 61

docs.snippet: Brazil brushed past Croatia, 4-0, yesterday in Nigeria to advance to the quarterfinals of the World Youth Championships.     The Brazilians, who have scored 12 goals in three games, will next play Uruguay, which struggled to beat a 10-man Paraguay...
docs.lead_paragraph: Brazil brushed past Croatia, 4-0, yesterday in Nigeria to advance to the quarterfinals of the World Youth Championships. The Brazilians, who have scored 12 goals in three games, will next play Uruguay, which struggled to beat a 10-man Paraguay team on penalty kicks, 10-9, after playing to a 2-2 draw.
docs.abstract: Brazil beats Croatia, 4-0, in Nigeria to advance to quarterfinals of World Youth Soccer Championships (S)

docs.snippet: Neither wind nor rain nor broken mast will keep the American solo sailor Brad Van Liew from the completion of his appointed round. Or so it appears.    Van Liew's odyssey in the Around Alone yacht race -- his first solo circumnavigation -- seemed...
docs.lead_paragraph: Neither wind nor rain nor broken mast will keep the American solo sailor Brad Van Liew from the completion of his appointed round. Or so it appears. Van Liew's odyssey in the Around Alone yacht race -- his first solo circumnavigation -- seemed over as recently as last Sunday, when he despondently reported that his 50-foot yacht Balance Bar had been dismasted in a fierce squall and 10-to-15-foot seas less than 90 miles out of Punta del Este, Uruguay. Van Liew and the eight other solo sailors in the fleet were one day out of port en route to Charleston, S.C., on the fourth and final leg of the 27,000-mile voyage that began last September.
docs.abstract: Fellow sailors rally to help Brad Van Liew, who is trying to complete Around Alone yacht race; photo (S)

headline.main: American Sailor in Distress Discovers Many Friends

docs.snippet: The Lannan Foundation of Santa Fe, N.M., announced yesterday that it would give its first $250,000 Prize for Cultural Freedom to the Uruguayan writer Eduardo Galeano. As part of the award, one of the cultural world's largest monetary prizes, the...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Lannan Foundation of Santa Fe, N.M., announced yesterday that it would give its first $250,000 Prize for Cultural Freedom to the Uruguayan writer Eduardo Galeano. As part of the award, one of the cultural world's largest monetary prizes, the foundation will also donate $100,000 to three charities of Mr. Galeano's choosing. Mr. Galeano, 58, is best known for his trilogy, ''Memory of Fire,'' which consists of poetic vignettes about the history of the Americas and indigenous peoples. It won the American Book Award in 1989. In 1974 he fled Uruguay after protesting Government violence and corruption. After a coup in Argentina, Mr. Galeano fled again, to Spain, where he lived until he returned to Uruguay in 1984.
docs.abstract: Lannan Foundation will give its first $250,000 Prize for Cultural Freedom to the Uruguayan writer Eduardo Galeano; will also donate $100,000 to three charities of his choosing; Galeano's Memory of Fire, triology consisting of poetic vignettes about history of Americas and indigenous peoples, won American Book Award in 1989; photo (M)

headline.main: In Its Debut, A Big Prize For Freedom Helps Writer

docs.snippet: Japan beat Uruguay, 2-1, yesterday to reach the final of the FIFA World Youth Championship in Nigeria.     Naohiro Takahara put Japan ahead in the 23d minute, but Ernesto Chevanton tied the score two minutes later. Yuichiro Nagai scored the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Japan beat Uruguay, 2-1, yesterday to reach the final of the FIFA World Youth Championship in Nigeria. Naohiro Takahara put Japan ahead in the 23d minute, but Ernesto Chevanton tied the score two minutes later. Yuichiro Nagai scored the game-winner in the 35th, putting Japan in a final of a FIFA competition for the first time.
docs.abstract: Japan will play Spain in FIFA World Youth Championship soccer final in Nigeria (S)

headline.main: Japan Will Face Spain in the Final

docs.snippet: Coach Bora Milutinovic of the MetroStars got the man he wanted as his assistant yesterday, Fernando Clavijo, a native of Uruguay and a naturalized American who started three games for the United States under Milutinovic in the 1994 World Cup.     The...
docs.lead_paragraph: Coach Bora Milutinovic of the MetroStars got the man he wanted as his assistant yesterday, Fernando Clavijo, a native of Uruguay and a naturalized American who started three games for the United States under Milutinovic in the 1994 World Cup. The 43-year-old Clavijo, who played in 61 games for the United States, will join the MetroStars immediately to help Milutinovic prepare for Sunday's game against the Tampa Bay Mutiny.
docs.abstract: Fernando Clavijo is named assistant coach of MetroStars (S)

docs.snippet: For decades after its founding in 1922 as the world's first state-owned oil company outside the Soviet Union, Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales was the butt of one of Argentina's most enduring jokes as ''the only oil company in the world that knew...
docs.lead_paragraph: For decades after its founding in 1922 as the world's first state-owned oil company outside the Soviet Union, Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales was the butt of one of Argentina's most enduring jokes as ''the only oil company in the world that knew how to lose money.'' Executives were chosen for their loyalty to a series of military dictators, even if they did not know the difference between crude and kerosene. It didn't matter: the union made key management decisions anyway. Meanwhile the rest of the Government's agencies, including the railroad and gas distribution company, balanced their books by neglecting to pay their fuel bills.
docs.abstract: Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales, or YPF--Argentina's formerly state-owned oil company--was once money loser; now headed by Roberto Monti, it has turned itself into profitable company by slashing its work force and jettisoning wasteful enterprises; YPF has thrust itself into second tier of world energy companies by expanding in Latin America and buying interests in oil and gas fields elsewhere; graph; map; photos (M)

headline.main: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Argentina's Rising Oil Fortunes; Privatized Company Gets Knack of Not Losing Money

headline.main: U.S. Treasury Is Set to Auction Bills and Notes

docs.snippet: ASIA    CHINA: TRADE MEMBERSHIP TALKS -- China and the U.S. extended talks in Beijing over China's proposed entry into the World Trade Organization. Working to preserve momentum that almost sealed a deal during Prime Minister Zhu Rongji's trip to the...
docs.lead_paragraph: ASIA CHINA: TRADE MEMBERSHIP TALKS -- China and the U.S. extended talks in Beijing over China's proposed entry into the World Trade Organization. Working to preserve momentum that almost sealed a deal during Prime Minister Zhu Rongji's trip to the U.S. earlier this month, American negotiators delayed a scheduled departure on Sunday and met again yesterday. The organization's Director-General, Renato Ruggiero, said he believed that China would join before November. Seth Faison (NYT) CHINA: DISSIDENT ON TRIAL -- A prominent dissident, Fang Jue, went on trial on fraud charges that human rights organizations say were fabricated. The trial, delayed so it would not coincide with Prime Minister Zhu Rongji's American trip, went into recess after four hours. Mr. Fang, 44, was arrested after he called for elections at all levels of government. Seth Faison (NYT)
